Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Challenges in Modern Astronomy VI
Award.AbstractNarration:
A conference on Statistical Challenges in Modern Astronomy VI will be held at Carnegie-Mellon University, June 6-10, 2016. (See http://www.scma6.org/.) Astronomical data are continuously being gathered from surveys that are increasingly ambitious in scope, and astronomers face a wide range of challenges when transforming this information into scientific conclusions. This conference brings together statisticians and astronomers to work on problems in astronomy involving large amounts of data. It has been held every five years since 1991.

The conference Statistical Challenges in Modern Astronomy VI will be held at Carnegie-Mellon University, June 6-10, 2016. Over 15 years the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) has collected 100 terabytes data from hundreds of millions of stars and galaxies, as well as a million supermassive black holes; by contrast, the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST), planned for completion by 2022, will gather 15 terabytes of data per night over its ten-year life. The full scientific potential of these surveys will be realized not only with ingenuity, but also with novel methods of data analysis. Experts in statistics and machine learning can make crucial contributions both to these specific domains, and to general methodological development for Big Data applications. This conference is a major effort to increase the interaction of astronomers and data scientists and to build the next generation of scientists to bridge the gap between these disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The week-long conference Statistical Challenges in Modern Astronomy VI, hosted at Carnegie Mellon University in June 2016, successfully brought together astronomers, cosmologists and experts in statistics and machine learning for a very useful exploration of some of the most pressing data analysis challenges facing researchers in astronomy. Topics covered included the analysis of data arising from study of the large scale structure of the Universe, weak lensing, time-varying astronomical objects, supernovae, and exoplanets. Sessions were also focused on the introduction of novel methods of analysis to the astronomical community. Methods included approximate Bayesian computation, deep learning, and variational Bayesian inference. Each of these topics were chosen for their direct relevance to astronomical applications.

Particular focus was placed on the analysis of data arising from ongoing and future astronomical surveys, including the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. A keynote presentation from LSST Project Scientist Zeljko Ivezic was a highlight of the conference, and served to focus on the specific needs of this upcoming survey.

There were forty poster presentations, adding substantial breadth to the topics covered at the conference. Many of the posters were presented by researchers in the early stages of their career.

There were 126 attendees, and 43 of them were provided with travel support. Twenty-six of these supported attendees were either Ph.D. students or postdocs. All of the talks remain available at scma6.org.
